Blog.post: 'Grandpa always said "The best stories: the ones most remembered and loved, are the ones that are true."' -Kayd The sun rose like a great king, spreading it's glory far and wide. Light was given to the land once again, and all around life had begin to stir. The gentle stream caressed the banks of the forest as a lonely colt stood, gazing at his reflection, wondering what would become of him as time passed by. Would he be a mighty stallion like his father, master of the forest, free to run with the wind, or a hapless gelding fated to be killed before his time? A sound from the east aroused the attention of the young colt. Before he could recognise what it was, a swiftly thrown noose wrapped around his neck. The colt struggled with all his might, but soon more ropes flew out, followed by cheers of joy and victory. Three old men walked up towards the defeated young horse. "Another great catch, eh Rob?" "Yeah, this one'll be a gift 'fer me daughter, Jakeb. A nice, tame young'un she can learn to ride," The colt threw his head up and called out for his mother. But, only silence replied, and told him he was all alone, without saying a word. Realising it was all up to him now, the young colt thrashed about, catching one of his captors in the groin with the force of the great stallion buried deep inside of him, sending the man to his knees in pain. "Hahaha!!! Mick, the 'lil bugger got ye good ey?" Mick lay sprawled on the forest floor, replying with an indifferent moan. Rob winced in sympathy for the poor man, but chuckled under his breath. "Er...on second thought, do you want 'em, Jakeb?" "What's the matter, Robb'o me lad? Too big 'fer ya? Haha! ...okay, I'll have 'em, but gimme a hand tyin' up his legs first. Don't wanna come home to me wife a 'lesser man', ey Mick?" With that, the men tied up the now exhausted young horse, and put him in the back of a rusted old van. The stallion in him subsided, and looking back, he realised that his days in the forest were over.

"The Beginning and The End… Life and Death… Truth and Lies… Light and Dark… Good and Evil… Existence and Nothingness… Love and Hate. Everything is made of opposing forces. Long ago, when the land was barren and young, the gods of our world fought an epic battle, deciding on which opposing force would be superior. Since the world was bare, the only weapons they could use were the powers they had been created with. The god of Divinity, Dalin, and his followers had the powers of life, light, and creation. They used their powers to give energy to this planet, create living creatures, and the sun that shone from high above the clouds to give warmth to the entire world. However, the god of Chaos, Faron, and his loyal minions had the powers of death, darkness and destruction. They used their powers to destroy everything they could, creating barren deserts once more across the world, and diseases that plagued all living things. Darkness rolled across the world, and many of the inhabitants of our world were destroyed. Some survived, and with the aid of the Divinities, were given the power of healing, magic and creation. These demi-gods worked with their creators, and drove the evil back into it’s own darkness. The land was restored to its state of serenity, and the creatures began to rebuild the world. New shrubs were planted, animals were created, and illness had disappeared once again. All was peaceful for a time, but after many years of harmony, the evil inside the creatures was slowly beginning to show. Some mastered the destructive side of the magic. Minor arguments turned to fights, and it wasn’t long before the world was once again at war. The gods, seeing what the creatures had done to their world, decided to reclaim the powers of magic from the people. They came down from the heavens and stole back the powers, leaving the people powerless once more. They sealed the powers inside a crystal, and shattered it into 10 pieces. Each piece was scattered across the planet, and embedded into only the most true and worthy of people. These beings had the power of the gods stored deep within them, and each their own unique task to complete; a driving force for their very existence. The tasks were a test, to see whether these creatures could truly learn to control such powers. Only when the task had been completed, was the true power released unto the creature. Legend states that when all 10 tasks are complete, the gods shall descend upon the land once again, and turn the world into a perfect utopia. Unfortunately, the legend also speaks of a terrible evil surrounding the crystals. If a task is abandoned or the person killed, the evil of the crystal is released. The forces of darkness feed off the evils of the crystal, and with each abandonment, they grow more powerful. If all of the carriers fail, or the creatures were to die, Faron may once again exterminate the inhabitants of this world, and give rise to his own creations." "Are you even paying attention to me, Kayd?" "Huh? Oh yeh, sure thing grandpa. I got the gist of it. Gods kill each other, crystal shatters, dudes die and evil wins. Great story. Hey, i gotta go. I'll catcha later."

A ray of light glistened through a hole in the curtains, which belonged to an open window of an old cottage in the outskirts of the town. Tiny flakes of snow along the window sparkled like diamonds in the light. Slowly, the beam of light crept up towards a wooden bed in the room, like a mischievous young lad planning to wake up his father with the crash of a saucepan. Along the intricate carvings on the legs and across the covers the light snuck, towards the face of a boy, fast asleep. The boy was dreaming of swash-buckling pirates with dazzling swords, and hidden treasures deep within the heart of a jungle somewhere far, far away. Suddenly, the wind rose up, coming through the window. Accompanying the beam of light in it's sinister prank, the wind pulled the curtains apart, and the light burst through the window, jumping on the boys face with all it's might. The boy stirred, let out an exhausted yawn, and rolled out of the light, murmuring incoherently. The light, in failing to wake the boy, scurried behind the safety of the curtains and hid from the room. The wind, however, was determined to wake the boy up. With an almighty gust of chilly winters wind, it filled the room. Snowflakes scattered all around, one landing on the boys cheek. Finally, the boy got up. Satisfied, the wind dissapeared without a trace, while the light still remained, determined now to fill the whole room as the wind did, and bring the day to one more person. The boy threw the covers off himself, stumbled over countless dirty shirts and underwear towards the curtains, groaned, and closed the window, pulling the curtains completely shut. The day was ready for the boy, but the boy wasn't ready for the day, and he went back to bed. "Get up, lazy ass!" A door creaked open, and an old man hobbled in carrying a bucket of icy cold water. "C'mon grandpa, it's too early, just gimme 5...10 more minutes..." "I said... get up!" The old man promptly poured the freezing cold water all over the boy, still in his covers, and put the half-full bucket down at the side of the bed. "I want this all out and ready to be dried now, Kayd. Hahaha!!!" Kayd 'decided' it was time to get up, and jumped out of his bed, soaking wet and cold. Chuckling to himself, Kayds grandpa started off towards the door, but was met by a barrage of soaked clothes and sheets, followed by the half filled bucket of water.
